statement:
*Theorem.*The set of all real transcendental numbers is uncountable.

*Proof.* Denote $\mathbb{T}$ and $\mathbb{A}$ be the set of real
transcendental and real algebraic numbers respectively. Suppose
$\mathbb{T}$ is countable. Then the union
$\mathbb{T} \cup \mathbb{A} = \mathbb{R}$ is also countable, since
$\mathbb{A}$ is also countable, which is a contradiction. Therefore
$\mathbb{T}$ must be uncountable. $\Box$
names: the set of all real transcendental numbers is uncountable
